source.da1c94da:
to_rename = {
    'ranking of movie': 'ranking',
    'movie name ': 'name',
    'Year': 'year',
    'runtime': 'length',
    'RATING': 'rating',
    'DIRECTOR ': 'director'
}

movies_df.rename(columns = to_rename, inplace = True)
source.87790637:
# Changing 'year' datatype
movies_df['year'] = movies_df['year'].str.replace('-', '')

movies_df['year'] = pd.to_datetime(movies_df['year'], errors = 'coerce').dt.year
movies_df['year'] = movies_df['year'].astype('Int64')
source.e8215afb:
# Changing 'length' datatype
movies_df['length'] = movies_df['length'].str.replace(' min', '')
movies_df['length'] = movies_df['length'].astype('int64')
source.4c72f3d8:
# Top per metascore
top_per_ms = movies_df[['name', 'metascore']].sort_values('metascore', ascending = False).head(10)

#Top per user rating
top_per_ur = movies_df[['name', 'rating']].sort_values('rating', ascending = False).head(10)
source.1c8ae2d4:
fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(2,1, figsize = (16,8))

ax1.set_title('Top 10 movies per Metascore')
ax1.set_xlim(95, 100)
sns.barplot(x = 'metascore', y = 'name', data = top_per_ms, ax = ax1, palette = 'dark:salmon_r');

ax2.set_title('Top 10 movies per User Rating')
ax2.set_xlim(8, 9.5)
sns.barplot(x = 'rating', y = 'name', data = top_per_ur, ax = ax2, palette = 'crest');

plt.tight_layout(pad= 2)
source.973429c8:
#Worst per metascore
worst_per_ms = movies_df[['name', 'metascore']].sort_values('metascore', ascending = True).head(10)

#Worst per user rating
worst_per_ur = movies_df[['name', 'rating']].sort_values('rating', ascending = True).head(10)
source.c7936c70:
fig, (ax1,ax2) = plt.subplots(2,1, figsize = (16,8))

ax1.set_title('Worst 10 movies per metascore')
ax1.set_xlim(50, 65)
sns.barplot(x = 'metascore', y = 'name', data = worst_per_ms, ax = ax1, palette = 'dark:salmon');

ax2.set_title('Worst 10 movies per User Rating')
ax2.set_xlim(8.0,8.2)
sns.barplot(x = 'rating', y = 'name', data  = worst_per_ur, ax =ax2, palette = 'crest_r');

plt.tight_layout(pad = 2)

source.60551e18:
![data-original.jpg](attachment:8a6002c6-fe9b-4e5a-ba07-94becd4df3f8.jpg)
The dataset is downloaded from [Kaggle](https://www.kaggle.com/ramjasmaurya/top-250s-in-imdb). The dataset contains 250 rows and 16 columns.
The dataset contains a list of the top 250 IMDb movies.

IMDb(Internet Movie Database) is an online database of information related to films, television series, home videos, video games, and streaming content online – including cast, production crew, and personal biographies, plot summaries, trivia, ratings, and fan, and critical reviews. IMDb began as a fan-operated movie database on the Usenet group "rec.arts.movies" in 1990, and moved to the web in 1993. It is now owned and operated by IMDb.com, Inc., a subsidiary of Amazon.

As of June 2021, the database contained some 8 million titles (including television episodes) and 10.4 million person records. Additionally, the site had 83 million registered users.
